page.title: 17Foxash Growers, Lawford
page.content: The Land Settlement Association (LSA) was formed by two charities (Plunkett Foundation and Carnegie Trust) in 1935 to provide work for out_of_work miners during the 1930's depression. In 1950's it fell into financial difficulties and was taken over by the Ministry of Agriculture Fishery's and Food. It was restructured to provide opportunities for horticultural and agricultural workers to set up their own businesses. The Foxash Estate in Lawford was one of ten, and comprised of sixty smallholdings which belonged to MAFF. The tenants owned their own glasshouses and sent their produce to a central packhouse for LSA marketing. LSA 1983 was set up to give growers a chance to form their own businesses because of the LSA closure in 1982. By Denise Howe, 12 years old
